oci image so you can have like a yaml file that says I want these packages
from these repositories signed with these Keys it'll go out and it'll set
all of that up and it will build the image and it'll
include all of those uh various configuration files behind so that you
can then take a scanner and see what is actually in the image and that's a
really big thing because a lot of people who make small images they they use from
scratch in a Docker file and then they copy everything over and if you do that
then your security scanning doesn't detect anything and that makes it a
nightmare for your security team because they have no idea what's in these images they don't know how to remediate
anything they don't know what to tell their developers to fix
and so it's very important that everything in an image is cataloged
somehow and basically the thing about apko is that
everything that goes into an image generated by apko has to be an APK package and as a
result everything is cataloged MHM in some way okay you know
so that brings us to to um s bombs the
software build materials that's kind of a the same Mantra applied

Computing and basically the idea is that all software needs to be

just enough to run a go application so KO kind of is like a

guard static image which is maintained by chainu guard obviously and that image contains only

for the print up function in muil it is right where you would expect it to be
there is no level of indirection there
basically musil's a lot simpler in terms of how it is implemented
and because of that the behavior is a lot more predictable there's a lot of features
that are security oriented especially in Musa 1.2 there's a new malok that is

most common thing that happens with muil is that that the

friction with muil because for example perhaps they are not
properly locking mutexes between threads and they'll Malo something on one thread
and then they'll free it from another thread muil will frequently fail in that
case because it is a the spec says that that is undefined Behavior arguably it
is dangerous for programs to continue running when they hit undefined Behavior
now that doesn't mean that programs should lock up in general in muil we try
to when we detect that a program has done something that isn't allowed by the
spec we call a special function called aore crash which is supposed to make the
compiler insert a uh undefined op code into the assembly and that is supposed
to make the program crash right at the point where the undefined Behavior was
encountered sometimes that's not the case where we can't actually prove that
uh defined Behavior occurred and so that's when you run into these cases where the program will lock up or you
might have a memory leak or something like that but usually in these cases that's
because we have found ourselves in a gray area and we don't know how to proceed in a safe way so we choose
the least bad option available to us sometimes that's not what the developer
wants but the point is if you're hitting weird Behavior with muil it's probably

or it is under specified impics and our interpretation tends to lean
conservative so we prefer to not

DK and we have all of these arguably broken d DNS servers out
